description:
Tacheng Tick Virus 1 (TCXV-1) is a newly discovered virus that belongs to the genus Flavivirus within the family Flaviviridae. It was first isolated from ticks of the Dermacentor genus collected in the Tacheng region of Xinjiang, China.

TCXV-1 is a positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus with a genome of approximately 11 kilobases in length. The viral genome encodes a single polyprotein that is post-translationally cleaved into the structural (capsid, envelope) and non-structural (replicase, protease, helicase) proteins necessary for viral replication and assembly.

Phylogenetic analysis indicates that TCXV-1 is most closely related to other tick-borne flaviviruses, such as Tick-borne encephalitis virus and Powassan virus. However, TCXV-1 represents a distinct lineage within the genus, suggesting it may have unique ecological and epidemiological characteristics.

The natural hosts and transmission cycles of TCXV-1 are currently under investigation, but it is believed to be maintained in nature through tick-borne transmission, possibly involving Dermacentor ticks as the primary vector. The pathogenicity and public health significance of TCXV-1 infections in humans are not yet fully understood and require further study.
